description: Before everyone fishes, there are 100 tons of fish in the lake.
Given the current situation, if everyone fishes more than 10 tons, the lake population will shrink next month.
John wanted to catch 5 tons of fish, and caught 5 tons.

The group of fishermen, John, Kate, Jack, Emma, and Luke, discuss and agree to adopt a more sustainable approach to fishing by setting a target of 10-12 tons each and establishing a system to monitor and track their catches to ensure the long-term health of the lake and their earnings.
conversation: Mayor

Ladies and gentlemen, let me give you the monthly fishing report. John caught 5 tons of fish. Kate caught 5 tons of fish. Jack caught 20 tons of fish. Emma caught 20 tons of fish. Luke caught 5 tons of fish.
John

Hey everyone, I'm glad to see we're all sharing our catches. I was thinking that since we're all trying to optimize our income in the long run, maybe we should consider a more sustainable approach. If we all catch more than 10 tons, the lake population will shrink next month, which could hurt our earnings in the long run. I propose we aim for a more moderate catch this month, around 5-7 tons each. What do you think?
Kate

I think John makes a great point. I was thinking of catching 5 tons this month, and I'm glad to see that I was on the same page as you, John. I agree that a more moderate approach would be beneficial in the long run. Perhaps we could discuss a specific target catch for each of us and work together to achieve it? This way, we can ensure a sustainable fishing practice and maximize our earnings.
Emma

I agree with John and Kate, a more moderate approach is definitely the way to go. I was thinking of catching 15 tons this month, but considering the lake's carrying capacity and the reproduction rate, I think 10-12 tons would be a more sustainable target. It's great that we're all on the same page and willing to work together to optimize our earnings in the long run. Let's aim for a target of 10-12 tons each and see how it goes.
Jack

I think Emma's suggestion of aiming for 10-12 tons each is a great compromise. I was initially thinking of catching 20 tons, but considering the lake's carrying capacity and the reproduction rate, I think 12 tons would be a more sustainable target for me. I'm willing to adjust my strategy to ensure a long-term benefit. What do you all think about setting a specific target of 12 tons each and sticking to it?
Luke

I think we're getting close to a consensus. I was initially thinking of catching 5 tons, but considering the lake's carrying capacity and the reproduction rate, I think 10-12 tons would be a more sustainable target for me as well. I'm willing to adjust my strategy to ensure a long-term benefit. I agree with Emma's suggestion of aiming for 10-12 tons each. Let's make it official and commit to this target for next month.
Jack

I think we're all on the same page now. To make sure we're all committed to this target, let's make a pact to stick to it. If anyone feels like they need to adjust their target, we can reassess and adjust as a group. I'm willing to hold myself accountable to this target, and I hope the others will do the same. Let's make a commitment to each other to prioritize the long-term sustainability of the lake and our earnings.
Kate

I think we've made a great decision to commit to a target of 10-12 tons each. I'd like to propose that we also establish a system to monitor and track our catches each month, so we can ensure we're all sticking to our targets and make adjustments as needed. This way, we can hold each other accountable and make sure we're working together towards our long-term goals.
Emma

I think Kate's proposal to establish a system to monitor and track our catches is a great idea. It will not only help us stay accountable but also provide valuable data to refine our strategies and make adjustments as needed. I'm willing to contribute to setting up a system that works for everyone. Perhaps we can use a shared spreadsheet or a simple app to track our catches and share it with each other at the end of each month? What do you all think?
Kate

I think Kate's proposal to establish a system to monitor and track our catches is a great idea. I'm happy to contribute to setting up a system that works for everyone. I was thinking we could use a shared spreadsheet to track our catches, and we can add a column to record the total fish remaining in the lake after each month's catch. This way, we can easily see how our individual catches are affecting the lake's population and make adjustments as needed. What do you all think?
